pull.title: Use a single wallet batch for UpgradeKeyMetadata
pull.body:
Opening wallets (the first time) after #14021 took on my end around 30 seconds due to the keymetadata migration (tested on regtest).

Using a single wallet batch reduces the required time for the migration down to <1s on my system for a default 2k keypool wallet.

verification.payload:
tree f31090773e75bb5c046e0c229bece22bc472a4bd
parent b72c787dc8f77dfeeab3774e9d84f03a066ff32e
author Jonas Schnelli <dev@jonasschnelli.ch> 1550460484 -1000
committer Jonas Schnelli <dev@jonasschnelli.ch> 1550467978 -1000

Use a single wallet batch for UpgradeKeyMetadata

events.message: Use a single wallet batch for UpgradeKeyMetadata

events.body: Tagged for 0.18 because I'd consider this a bugfix

Concept ACK.

We should also consider doing that for `importmulti` (at least per descriptor).

utACK https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/0bedcbafdfaa0e980ad91c0ba4b9039575017f0e

@achow101 want to take a look?

Concept ACK.

On line 387, before throwing, shouldn't it commit the batch?
@promag Wouldn't it doe that, as the unique ptr gets destroyed (and flush on exit was set to `true` by default)?

@MarcoFalke yap, it wasn't clear. Maybe worth a comment.

@jonasschnelli is there a rationale for 1000?

> On line 387, before throwing, shouldn't it commit the batch?

As @MarcoFalke said, if the unique pointer gets out of the scope, it "commits" (flushes) to the database.

> @jonasschnelli is there a rationale for 1000?

Not really. I thought 1000 is a good compromise between cache memory requirements and performance. A new constant looked after an overkill. Initially I wanted to tie it to the keypool size constant but somehow I thought then that this has nothing to do with memory consumption.

1000 seems like a good upper bound, since the speedup flattens out after this:

(time in us)

![upgradekeymetadata time](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6399679/52975475-b1572c00-3393-11e9-92ed-f5483b428452.png)

issue.title: Batch write imported stuff in importmulti
issue.body:
Instead of writing each item to the wallet database individually, do them in batches so that the import runs faster.

This was tested by importing a ranged descriptor for 10,000 keys.

Current master

```
$ time src/bitcoin-cli -regtest -rpcwallet=importbig importmulti '[{"desc": "sh(wpkh([73111820/44h/1h/0h]tpubDDoT2SgEjaU5rerQpfcRDWPAcwyZ5g7xxHgVAfPwidgPDKVjm89d6jJ8AQotp35Np3m6VaysfUY1C2g68wFqUmraGbzhSsMF9YBuTGxpBaW/1/*))#3w7php47", "range": [0, 10000], "timestamp": "now", "internal": true, "keypool": false, "watchonly": true}]'
...

real	7m45.29s
```

This PR:

```
$ time src/bitcoin-cli -regtest -rpcwallet=importbig4 importmulti '[{"desc": "pkh([73111820/44h/1h/0h]tpubDDoT2SgEjaU5rerQpfcRDWPAcwyZ5g7xxHgVAfPwidgPDKVjm89d6jJ8AQotp35Np3m6VaysfUY1C2g68wFqUmraGbzhSsMF9YBuTGxpBaW/1/*)#v65yjgmc", "range": [0, 10000], "timestamp": "now", "internal": true, "keypool": false, "watchonly": true}]'
...

real	3.93s
```

Fixes #15739
